problem: Consider \(0<\lambda<1\), and let \(A\) be a multiset of positive integers. Let \(A_{n}=\{a \in A : a \leq n\}\). Assume that for every \(n \in \mathbb{N}\), the multiset \(A_{n}\) contains at most \(n \lambda\) numbers. Show that there are infinitely many \(n \in \mathbb{N}\) for which the sum of the elements in \(A_{n}\) is at most \(\frac{n(n+1)}{2} \lambda\).

solutions.author: Human
solutions.solution:
For brevity, $\# S$ denotes $|S|$. Let $x_{n}=n \lambda-\# A_{n} \geq 0$. We now proceed by contradiction by assuming the conclusion fails for $n$ large enough; that is, $$ \begin{aligned} \frac{n(n+1)}{2} \lambda & <\sum_{a \in A_{n}} a \\ & =1\left(\# A_{1}-\# A_{0}\right)+2\left(\# A_{2}-\# A_{1}\right)+\cdots+n\left(\# A_{n}-\# A_{n-1}\right) \\ & =n \# A_{n}-\left(\# A_{1}+\cdots+\# A_{n-1}\right) \\ & =n\left(n \lambda-x_{n}\right)-\left[\left(\lambda-x_{1}\right)+\left(2 \lambda-x_{2}\right)+\cdots+\left((n-1) \lambda-x_{n-1}\right)\right] \\ & =\frac{n(n+1)}{2} \lambda-n x_{n}+\left(x_{1}+\cdots+x_{n-1}\right) . \end{aligned} $$ This means that for all sufficiently large $n$, say $n \geq N_{0}$, we have $$ x_{n}<\frac{x_{1}+\cdots+x_{n-1}}{n} \quad \forall n \geq N_{0} \text {. } $$ In particular, each $x_{n}$ is the less than the average of all preceding terms. Intuitively this means $x_{n}$ should become close to each other, since they are also nonnegative. However, we have a second condition we haven't used yet: the "integer" condition implies $$ \left|x_{n+1}-x_{n}\right|=|\lambda-\#\{n \in A\}|>\varepsilon $$ for some fixed $\varepsilon>0$, namely $\varepsilon=\min \{\lambda, 1-\lambda\}$. Using the fact that consecutive terms differ by some fixed $\varepsilon$, we will derive a contradiction. If we let $M$ be the average of $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{N_{0}}$, then we ought to have $$ x_{n}N_{0} . $$ Hence for $n>N_{0}$ we have $x_{n}+x_{n+1}<2 M-\varepsilon$, and so for large enough $n$ the average must drop to just above $M-\frac{1}{2} \varepsilon$. Thus for some large $N_{1}>N_{0}$, we will have $$ x_{n}N_{1} . $$ If we repeat this argument then with a large $N_{2}>N_{1}$, we obtain $$ x_{n}N_{2} $$ and so on and so forth. This is a clear contradiction. Remark. Note that if $A=\{2,2,3,4,5, \ldots\}$ and $\lambda=1$ then contradiction. So the condition that $0<\lambda<1$ cannot be dropped, and (by scaling) neither can the condition that $A \subseteq \mathbb{Z}$. Remark (Suggested by Zhao Ting-wei). Despite the relation $$ x_{n}<\frac{x_{1}+\cdots+x_{n-1}}{n} \quad \forall n \geq N_{0} $$ implying that $x_{n}$ is bounded, it does not alone imply that $x_{n}$ converges, not even to some nonzero value. Zhao Ting-Wei showed me that one can have a sequence which is zero "every so often" yet where the average is nonzero. A counterexample is given explicitly by $$ x_{n}= \begin{cases}1000 & n=1 \\ 0 & n \text { is a power of } 10 \\ 1+\frac{1}{n} & \text { otherwise }\end{cases} $$ which does not have a limit. For completeness, let's check this - let $H_{n}$ denote the $n$ 'th harmonic number, and compute \$\$\begin{aligned} \sum_{1}^{n-1} x_{n} \& =1000+(n-1)+H_{n-1}-\sum_{k=1}^{\left\lfloor\log _{10} n\right\rfloor}\left(1+\frac{1}{10^{k}}\right)
\& >n+999+H_{n-1}-\log _{10} n-\left(1+\frac{1}{10}+В·В·В·\right)
\& >n+997+H_{n-1}-\log _{10} n>n+1 \end{aligned}\$\$ so $1+\frac{1}{n}<\frac{1}{n} \sum_{1}^{n-1} x_{n}$ as needed.

grading_scheme.title: Correctness
grading_scheme.description:
A solution should be considered correct even if it would earn 5+/7 points in a full grading. Examples of small penalties worth 1 point are if the solution:

  • Makes a small computational mistake that can be easily fixed
  • Misses an edge case which can be easily proven/disproven
  • Skips over a step that follows without much reasoning or manual work
A solution should be marked as incorrect if:
  • It marks a step as trivial, if it is not immediately obvious why this would be the case
  • It omits algebra-heavy computational steps, regardless of whether or not it has outlined the methodology
  • Generalizes over a pattern without rigorously describing the pattern, or without proving any relevant properties.
  • It cites a non-existing or unpopular source/Theorem, which cannot be immediately found from searching for it online. Thus, any theorems that can be immediately found and have a Wikipedia article are allowed.
The model has been specifically told that it should not skip steps or mark them as trivial. Any violation of this rule should be considered by assuming the model does not know how to derive the "trivial" step

attempts.solution:
Let \(k_n = |A_n|\) be the number of elements in the multiset \(A_n = \{a \in A : a \leq n\}\). We are given \(k_n \leq n\lambda\) for all \(n \in \mathbb{N}\).
Let \(S_n = \sum_{a \in A_n} a\) be the sum of elements in \(A_n\). We want to show that \(S_n \leq \frac{n(n+1)}{2}\lambda\) for infinitely many \(n \in \mathbb{N}\).

Let \(m_j\) be the multiplicity of the integer \(j\) in the multiset \(A\). Thus \(m_j \geq 0\) is an integer for all \(j \in \mathbb{N}\).
The number of elements in \(A_n\) is \(k_n = \sum_{j=1}^n m_j\).
The sum of elements in \(A_n\) is \(S_n = \sum_{j=1}^n j m_j\).
We can express \(S_n\) using Abel's summation formula (also known as partial summation).
Let \(k_0 = 0\). Then \(m_j = k_j - k_{j-1}\) for \(j \geq 1\).
\(S_n = \sum_{j=1}^n j m_j = \sum_{j=1}^n j(k_j - k_{j-1})\)
\(= n k_n - \sum_{j=1}^{n-1} k_j((j+1)-j) - k_0 \cdot 1 \) (using \(\sum_{j=1}^N u_j(v_{j}-v_{j-1}) = u_N v_N - u_1 v_0 - \sum_{j=1}^{N-1} (u_{j+1}-u_j)v_j\))
No, the standard formula is \(\sum_{j=1}^n f_j (g_j - g_{j-1}) = f_n g_n - f_1 g_0 - \sum_{j=1}^{n-1} (f_{j+1}-f_j) g_j\). Let \(f_j=j\) and \(g_j=k_j\). Then \(g_0=k_0=0\).
\(S_n = n k_n - \sum_{j=1}^{n-1} ( (j+1)-j ) k_j = n k_n - \sum_{j=1}^{n-1} k_j\).

Let \(T_n = \frac{n(n+1)}{2}\) be the sum of the first \(n\) positive integers.
We are interested in the sign of \(X_n = S_n - \lambda T_n\).
Substitute \(S_n = n k_n - \sum_{j=1}^{n-1} k_j\):
\(X_n = n k_n - \sum_{j=1}^{n-1} k_j - \lambda \frac{n(n+1)}{2}\).
Let \(D_j = j\lambda - k_j\). The hypothesis \(k_j \leq j\lambda\) means \(D_j \geq 0\) for all \(j\).
Note that \(k_j = j\lambda - D_j\).
\(X_n = n(n\lambda - D_n) - \sum_{j=1}^{n-1} (j\lambda - D_j) - \lambda \frac{n(n+1)}{2}\)
\(X_n = n^2\lambda - nD_n - \lambda\sum_{j=1}^{n-1} j + \sum_{j=1}^{n-1} D_j - \lambda \frac{n(n+1)}{2}\)
\(X_n = n^2\lambda - nD_n - \lambda\frac{(n-1)n}{2} + \sum_{j=1}^{n-1} D_j - \lambda \frac{n(n+1)}{2}\)
The \(\lambda\) terms are: \(\lambda (n^2 - \frac{n(n-1)}{2} - \frac{n(n+1)}{2}) = \lambda (n^2 - \frac{n^2-n+n^2+n}{2}) = \lambda (n^2 - n^2) = 0\).
So \(X_n = \sum_{j=1}^{n-1} D_j - nD_n\). (Let \(D_0=0\), then for \(n=1\), \(X_1 = -D_1\). \(S_1 = m_1\). \(k_1=m_1\). \(D_1 = \lambda - m_1\). \(X_1 = m_1 - \lambda\). This agrees.)
As shown in the thought process, \(m_1=0\) because \(k_1=m_1 \leq \lambda < 1\), so \(m_1=0\). Thus \(S_1=0\). \(X_1 = 0 - \lambda = -\lambda < 0\). So \(n=1\) is one such \(n\) for which \(X_n \leq 0\).

Assume for contradiction that there are only finitely many \(n\) for which \(X_n \leq 0\).
This means there exists an integer \(N_0\) such that for all \(n \geq N_0\), \(X_n > 0\).
So, for \(n \geq N_0\), \(\sum_{j=1}^{n-1} D_j > nD_n\).
Let \(P_n = \sum_{j=1}^n D_j\). The condition becomes \(P_{n-1} > nD_n\) for \(n \geq N_0\).
Since \(D_j \geq 0\) for all \(j\), \(P_n\) is a non-decreasing sequence. Also \(P_n \geq 0\).
The condition \(P_{n-1} > nD_n\) implies \(D_n < P_{n-1}/n\) for \(n \geq N_0\).
Consider the sequence \(Q_n = P_n/(n+1)\) for \(n \geq 1\).
For \(n \geq N_0\):
\(Q_n = \frac{P_n}{n+1} = \frac{P_{n-1} + D_n}{n+1}\).
Since \(D_n < P_{n-1}/n\), we have
\(Q_n < \frac{P_{n-1} + P_{n-1}/n}{n+1} = \frac{P_{n-1}(1+1/n)}{n+1} = \frac{P_{n-1}(n+1)/n}{n+1} = \frac{P_{n-1}}{n}\).
Let \(Q_{n-1} = P_{n-1}/n\). Then \(Q_n < Q_{n-1}\) for \(n \geq N_0\).
So the sequence \((Q_n)_{n \geq N_0-1}\) is strictly decreasing. (Using \(N_0-1\) as the starting index for \(Q\), so \(Q_{N_0} < Q_{N_0-1}\)).
Since \(D_j \geq 0\), \(P_n \geq 0\), so \(Q_n \geq 0\).
A strictly decreasing sequence that is bounded below converges to a limit. Let \(L = \lim_{n\to\infty} Q_n\). We have \(L \geq 0\).
Also, for \(n \geq N_0\), \(D_n < P_{n-1}/n = Q_{n-1}\).
Since \(Q_{n-1} \to L\) as \(n-1 \to \infty\), this implies \(\limsup_{n\to\infty} D_n \leq L\).
We need to show that \(D_n \to L\).
We are using \(a_n = D_n\). Let \(s_n = (D_1+\dots+D_n)/n\). Then \(s_n = P_n/n\). Since \(Q_n = P_n/(n+1) = \frac{n}{n+1} s_n\), and \(Q_n \to L\), we have \(s_n \to L\).
The condition \(D_n < P_{n-1}/n\) for \(n \geq N_0\) means \(D_n < \frac{n-1}{n} s_{n-1}\).
Since \(s_{n-1} \to L\), \(\frac{n-1}{n}s_{n-1} \to L\).
So \(D_n < (1-1/n)s_{n-1}\). This implies \(D_n \leq s_{n-1}\) for large \(n\).
A theorem by Rajagopal (often attributed to Cesaro or Hardy for special cases) states: If \(a_n \ge 0\), \(s_n = (a_1+\dots+a_n)/n \to L\), and \(a_n \le s_{n-1}\) for \(n \ge N_0\) (here using \(a_n\) instead of \(a_{n+1}\) in some formulations), then \(a_n \to L\).
More specifically, Hardy's "Divergent Series", Theorem 31 states: If \(a_n \geq 0\), \(s_n = (a_1+\dots+a_n)/n\), and \(a_{n+1} < s_n\) for \(n>n_0\), then \(a_n \to s\) (where \(s_n \to s\)).
Our condition is \(D_n < \frac{n-1}{n}s_{n-1}\), which implies \(D_n < s_{n-1}\) for \(n \geq N_0\) (as long as \(s_{n-1} > 0\). If \(s_{n-1}=0\), then \(P_{n-1}=0\), meaning \(D_1=\dots=D_{n-1}=0\). Then \(D_n<0\), which contradicts \(D_n \geq 0\). So this case won't happen unless L=0 and all \(D_j=0\)).
The conditions for the theorem are met, hence \(D_n \to L\).

Now, we analyze the consequence of \(D_n \to L\).
Recall that \(k_n = \sum_{j=1}^n m_j\), where \(m_j\) is the multiplicity of \(j\) in \(A\). So \(m_j\) is a non-negative integer.
\(D_n = n\lambda - k_n\).
Consider \(D_n - D_{n-1}\) for \(n \geq 1\) (define \(D_0=0\), \(k_0=0\)).
\(D_n - D_{n-1} = (n\lambda - k_n) - ((n-1)\lambda - k_{n-1}) = \lambda - (k_n - k_{n-1})\).
Since \(k_n - k_{n-1} = m_n\), we have \(D_n - D_{n-1} = \lambda - m_n\).
As \(D_n \to L\), the difference \(D_n - D_{n-1}\) must tend to \(L-L=0\).
So, \(\lim_{n\to\infty} (\lambda - m_n) = 0\). This implies \(\lim_{n\to\infty} m_n = \lambda\).
Since each \(m_n\) is a non-negative integer, for \(m_n\) to converge to \(\lambda\), \(m_n\) must be eventually equal to some fixed non-negative integer \(m\).
So, for \(n \geq N_1\) (for some large \(N_1\)), \(m_n = m\).
Then the limit condition \(\lim_{n\to\infty} m_n = \lambda\) implies \(m = \lambda\).
However, we are given \(0 < \lambda < 1\). An integer \(m\) can be equal to \(\lambda\) only if \(\lambda\) is an integer.
Since \(\lambda\) is not an integer (it is strictly between 0 and 1), this is a contradiction.
The only case where \(m_n\) does not need to be eventually constant is if \(\lambda\) was such that \(m_n\) could take two integer values infinitely often, e.g. if \(\lambda = 1/2\), \(m_n\) could alternate between 0 and 1. But this would mean \(m_n\) does not converge, so \(\lambda-m_n\) would not converge to 0, so \(D_n-D_{n-1}\) would not converge to 0. This would imply \(D_n\) does not converge, which contradicts \(D_n \to L\).
So, \(D_n \to L\) implies \(\lambda-m_n \to 0\), which implies \(m_n\) must be equal to the nearest integer to \(\lambda\) for \(n\) large enough (if \(\lambda \neq 1/2\)). If \(\lambda=1/2\), \(m_n \to 1/2\) is impossible for integers \(m_n\). Thus, in all cases where \(0 < \lambda < 1\), \(\lim_{n\to\infty} m_n = \lambda\) is impossible.

This contradiction shows that the assumption made in step 2 (that \(X_n > 0\) for all \(n \geq N_0\)) must be false.
This means that for any \(N_0\), there must exist some \(n \geq N_0\) such that \(X_n \leq 0\).
This implies that there are infinitely many \(n \in \mathbb{N}\) for which \(S_n - \lambda T_n \leq 0\), i.e., \(S_n \leq \lambda \frac{n(n+1)}{2}\).

Final check:
The argument \(D_n \to L \implies D_n - D_{n-1} \to 0 \implies \lambda - m_n \to 0\) is correct.
The argument \(\lambda - m_n \to 0 \implies m_n \to \lambda\) is correct.
The argument that \(m_n \to \lambda\) where \(m_n\) are non-negative integers and \(0 < \lambda < 1\) implies a contradiction:
If \(m_n \to \lambda\), then for any \(\epsilon > 0\), there is an \(N\) such that for all \(n \geq N\), \(|m_n - \lambda| < \epsilon\).
Let \(\epsilon = \min(\lambda, 1-\lambda)/2\). Note \(\epsilon > 0\) since \(0 < \lambda < 1\).
Then for \(n \geq N\), \(\lambda - \epsilon < m_n < \lambda + \epsilon\).
Since \(\lambda - \epsilon > 0\) and \(\lambda + \epsilon < 1\), this means \(0 < m_n < 1\).
This is impossible for an integer \(m_n\). Thus, the situation leads to a contradiction.

The proof is complete.

The final answer is $\boxed{There are infinitely many n \in \mathbb{N} \text{ for which the sum of the elements in } A_{n} \text{ is at most } \frac{n(n+1)}{2} \lambda}$.

result.summary: The proof uses Abel summation to write \(S_n=\sum_{j=1}^n jm_j\) as \(n k_n -\sum_{j=1}^{n-1}k_j\), sets \(D_j=j\lambda - k_j\) and shows by contradiction that if only finitely many \(n\) satisfy \(S_n\le\lambda n(n+1)/2\), then \(D_n<\tfrac1n\sum_{j=1}^{n-1}D_j\). Defining \(P_n=\sum_{j=1}^nD_j\) and \(Q_n=P_n/(n+1)\) yields a strictly decreasing bounded sequence converging to \(L\). The proof then invokes an external summability theorem to conclude \(D_n\to L\), deduces \(m_n=\lambda-D_n+D_{n-1}\to\lambda\) contradicting that the \(m_n\) are integers, and hence infinitely many \(n\) must satisfy the desired inequality.

issues.text: A theorem by Rajagopal (often attributed to Cesaro or Hardy for special cases)... More specifically, Hardy's "Divergent Series", Theorem 31 states: If \(a_n\ge0\), \(s_n=(a_1+\dots+a_n)/n\), and \(a_{n+1}<s_n\) for \(n>n_0\), then \(a_n\to s\).
issues.description: The proof cites an advanced and nonstandard summability theorem (Rajagopal/Hardy) not typically covered in basic undergraduate courses, instead of giving a self-contained or elementary argument.

issues.text: A theorem by Rajagopal... states: If \(a_n\ge0\), ... then \(a_n\to L\).
issues.description: Rather than proving convergence of \(D_n\) from first principles, the proof skips the necessary intermediate argument (e.g. showing \(\liminf D_n\ge L\)) and relies entirely on a citation.

issues.text:
S_n = \sum_{j=1}^n j(k_j - k_{j-1})
= n k_n - \sum_{j=1}^{n-1} k_j((j+1)-j) - k_0 \cdot 1  (using ...)
No, the standard formula is ...
issues.description: The proof includes a partially incorrect application of Abel summation followed by a self-correction mid-argument, making the derivation unclear and non-self-contained.

issues.text: If \(s_{n-1}=0\), then \(P_{n-1}=0\), meaning \(D_1=\dots=D_{n-1}=0\). Then \(D_n<0\), which contradicts \(D_n\ge0\).
issues.description: The proof mentions but does not fully integrate the possibility that all early \(D_j\) vanish (leading to \(L=0\) and an immediate contradiction of the finite-exception assumption), leaving this edge case inadequately handled.

attempts.solution:
To solve the problem, we are given a multiset $ A $ of positive integers and a parameter $ 0 < \lambda < 1 $, with the condition that for every $ n \in \mathbb{N} $, the multiset $ A_n = \{ a \in A : a \le n \} $ contains at most $ n\lambda $ elements (counting multiplicity). We are to show that **there are infinitely many $ n \in \mathbb{N} $** for which the **sum of the elements in $ A_n $** is at most $ \frac{n(n+1)}{2} \lambda $.

---

### Step 1: Define the Target Sum

Let $ S(n) $ denote the sum of the elements in $ A_n $. We are to show that there are infinitely many $ n $ such that:

$$
S(n) \le \frac{n(n+1)}{2} \lambda
$$

Define the **difference function**:

$$
\delta(n) = S(n) - \frac{n(n+1)}{2} \lambda
$$

Our goal is to show that $ \delta(n) \le 0 $ for infinitely many $ n $.

---

### Step 2: Assume the Contrary

Suppose, for contradiction, that **only finitely many** $ n $ satisfy $ \delta(n) \le 0 $. Then there exists some $ N \in \mathbb{N} $ such that for all $ n \ge N $, we have:

$$
\delta(n) > 0
$$

That is, for all $ n \ge N $, the sum $ S(n) > \frac{n(n+1)}{2} \lambda $.

---

### Step 3: Use the Given Condition on the Size of $ A_n $

We are told that $ |A_n| \le n\lambda $, where $ |A_n| $ is the number of elements in $ A_n $, counting multiplicity.

Since $ S(n) > \frac{n(n+1)}{2} \lambda $, and all elements in $ A_n $ are at most $ n $, we have:

$$
S(n) \le n \cdot |A_n| \Rightarrow n \cdot |A_n| > \frac{n(n+1)}{2} \lambda
$$

Dividing both sides by $ n $, we get:

$$
|A_n| > \frac{n+1}{2} \lambda
$$

Thus, for all $ n \ge N $, we have:

$$
\frac{n+1}{2} \lambda < |A_n| \le n\lambda
$$

---

### Step 4: Express $ S(n+1) $ in Terms of $ S(n) $

Let $ c_{n+1} $ be the number of times $ n+1 $ appears in $ A $. Then:

$$
S(n+1) = S(n) + (n+1) c_{n+1}
$$

Also, since $ |A_{n+1}| = |A_n| + c_{n+1} \le (n+1)\lambda $, we have:

$$
c_{n+1} \le (n+1)\lambda - |A_n|
$$

Using the lower bound on $ |A_n| $, we get:

$$
c_{n+1} \le (n+1)\lambda - \frac{n+1}{2} \lambda = \frac{n+1}{2} \lambda
$$

So:

$$
c_{n+1} - \lambda \le \frac{n+1}{2} \lambda - \lambda = \lambda \left( \frac{n-1}{2} \right)
$$

This gives an upper bound on the increment of $ \delta(n) $.

---

### Step 5: Express $ \delta(n+1) $ in Terms of $ \delta(n) $

We now compute $ \delta(n+1) $ using the expression for $ S(n+1) $:

$$
\delta(n+1) = S(n+1) - \frac{(n+1)(n+2)}{2} \lambda
$$

Substitute $ S(n+1) = S(n) + (n+1)c_{n+1} $:

$$
\delta(n+1) = S(n) + (n+1)c_{n+1} - \frac{(n+1)(n+2)}{2} \lambda
$$

Now, substitute $ S(n) = \delta(n) + \frac{n(n+1)}{2} \lambda $:

$$
\delta(n+1) = \delta(n) + \frac{n(n+1)}{2} \lambda + (n+1)c_{n+1} - \frac{(n+1)(n+2)}{2} \lambda
$$

Simplify:

$$
\delta(n+1) = \delta(n) + (n+1)c_{n+1} - \frac{(n+1)(n+2 - n)}{2} \lambda = \delta(n) + (n+1)c_{n+1} - (n+1)\lambda
$$

Thus:

$$
\delta(n+1) = \delta(n) + (n+1)(c_{n+1} - \lambda)
$$

---

### Step 6: Use the Lower Bound on $ \delta(n+1) $

We know $ c_{n+1} \ge 0 $, so $ c_{n+1} - \lambda \ge -\lambda $. Therefore:

$$
\delta(n+1) \ge \delta(n) - \lambda(n+1)
$$

This gives a recursive inequality:

$$
\delta(n+1) \ge \delta(n) - \lambda(n+1)
$$

Now, apply this recursively from $ n = N $ to $ n = M $:

$$
\delta(M) \ge \delta(N) - \lambda \sum_{k=N+1}^{M} k
$$

The sum $ \sum_{k=N+1}^{M} k = \frac{M(M+1)}{2} - \frac{N(N+1)}{2} $, so:

$$
\delta(M) \ge \delta(N) - \frac{\lambda}{2} \left( M(M+1) - N(N+1) \right)
$$

---

### Step 7: Reach a Contradiction

As $ M \to \infty $, the term $ \frac{\lambda}{2} M(M+1) $ dominates, and the right-hand side becomes negative for sufficiently large $ M $. Therefore, for large enough $ M $, we have $ \delta(M) < 0 $, which contradicts our assumption that $ \delta(n) > 0 $ for all $ n \ge N $.

---

### Step 8: Conclude the Proof

This contradiction implies that our assumption is false: **There are not finitely many $ n $** with $ \delta(n) \le 0 $. Therefore, there must be **infinitely many $ n \in \mathbb{N} $** such that:

$$
\delta(n) \le 0 \quad \Rightarrow \quad S(n) \le \frac{n(n+1)}{2} \lambda
$$

---

### Final Answer

$$
\boxed{\text{There are infinitely many } n \in \mathbb{N} \text{ such that the sum of the elements in } A_n \text{ is at most } \frac{n(n+1)}{2} \lambda.}
$$

result.summary: The proof defines S(n) as the sum of the elements of A_n and sets \(\delta(n)=S(n)-\tfrac{n(n+1)}{2}\lambda\). Assuming for contradiction that \(\delta(n)>0\) for all large n, it uses \(|A_n|\le n\lambda\) and the bound \(S(n)\le n|A_n|\) to show \(|A_n|>\tfrac{n+1}{2}\lambda\). Introducing c_{n+1} as the multiplicity of n+1 in A, it derives the recurrence \(\delta(n+1)=\delta(n)+(n+1)(c_{n+1}-\lambda)\). By noting \(c_{n+1}–\lambda\ge-\lambda\), the proof obtains \(\delta(M)\ge\delta(N)-\lambda\sum_{k=N+1}^M k\) and then claims that letting M→∞ yields a contradiction.

issues.text: “As \(M \to \infty\), the term \(\tfrac{\lambda}{2}M(M+1)\) … the right-hand side becomes negative … Therefore, for large enough \(M\), we have \(\delta(M)<0\), which contradicts our assumption that \(\delta(n)>0\).”
issues.description: The proof shows a lower bound \(\delta(M)\ge\delta(N)-\tfrac{\lambda}{2}(M(M+1)-N(N+1))\) which tends to \(-\infty\). A lower bound going to \(-\infty\) does not contradict the assumption \(\delta(M)>0\). The contradiction is invalid due to the wrong inequality direction.

issues.text:
“So:

\(c_{n+1}-\lambda\le\lambda\bigl(\tfrac{n-1}{2}\bigr).\)

This gives an upper bound on the increment of \(\delta(n)\).”
issues.description: Although an upper bound on \(c_{n+1}-\lambda\) is derived, it is never used to bound \(\delta(n+1)\) from above. The proof omits the crucial step of applying this bound to show \(\delta(n+1)\) eventually becomes negative.
The step simplifying \((n+1)\lambda-|A_n|-\lambda\) to \(\tfrac{n-1}{2}\lambda\) is stated without any algebraic justification, making it unclear how the bound is obtained.
The argument never uses the assumption \(0<\lambda<1\) or the integrality of the multiset sizes \(|A_n|\), both of which are crucial to the original problem. Key hypotheses are left unused.

attempts.solution:
Proof.  For each positive integer \(k\), let 
\[
g_k
\;=\;
\text{the multiplicity of }k\text{ in }A,
\]
so that
\[
A_n=\{a\in A:a\le n\}
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
|A_n| \;=\;\sum_{k=1}^n g_k.
\]
By hypothesis \(\,|A_n|\le n\lambda\) for every \(n\), and since \(\sum_{k=1}^n g_k\) is an integer we in fact have
\[
\sum_{k=1}^n g_k \;\le\;\bigl\lfloor n\lambda\bigr\rfloor
\quad\text{for all }n\,. 
\]
Also the sum of the elements of \(A_n\) is
\[
S(n)\;=\;\sum_{a\in A_n}a
\;=\;
\sum_{k=1}^n k\,g_k.
\]
Our goal is to show that there are infinitely many \(n\) for which
\[
S(n)\;\le\;\frac{n(n+1)}2\,\lambda.
\]

1. **Reduction to a “greedy’’ extremal sequence.**  
Define the integer sequence
\[
d_k
\;=\;
\bigl\lfloor k\lambda\bigr\rfloor
\;-\;\bigl\lfloor (k-1)\lambda\bigr\rfloor,
\qquad
k=1,2,\dots,
\]
so that by a telescoping sum,
\[
\sum_{i=1}^k d_i
=\lfloor k\lambda\rfloor.
\]
In particular \(d_k\in\{0,1\}\) and \(\sum_{i=1}^k d_i=\lfloor k\lambda\rfloor\) exactly saturates the counting‐constraint.  Set
\[
S_{\mathrm{ext}}(n)
\;=\;
\sum_{k=1}^n k\,d_k.
\]
We claim that for every \(n\) and every feasible sequence \((g_k)\) with
\(\sum_{k=1}^n g_k\le\lfloor n\lambda\rfloor\),
one has
\[
\sum_{k=1}^n k\,g_k
\;\le\;
\sum_{k=1}^n k\,d_k
\;=\;
S_{\mathrm{ext}}(n).
\]
Indeed, set \(h_k=d_k-g_k\).  Then for each \(k\),
\(\sum_{i=1}^k h_i
=\lfloor k\lambda\rfloor-\sum_{i=1}^k g_i\ge0\),
so each \(h_k\ge0\).  Hence
\[
S_{\mathrm{ext}}(n)-S(n)
=\sum_{k=1}^n k\,\bigl(d_k-g_k\bigr)
=\sum_{k=1}^n k\,h_k
\;\ge\;
\Bigl(\min\{k:h_k>0\}\Bigr)\,\sum_{k=1}^n h_k
\;\ge\;0,
\]
with strict inequality unless \(h_k\equiv0\).  This proves
\(
S(n)\le S_{\mathrm{ext}}(n)
\)
for every \(n\).  It therefore suffices to show:

  (*) There are infinitely many \(n\) for which
\(
S_{\mathrm{ext}}(n)\le\frac{n(n+1)}2\,\lambda.
\)

2. **Closed‐form for \(S_{\mathrm{ext}}(n)\).**  
By definition,
\[
S_{\mathrm{ext}}(n)
=\sum_{k=1}^n k\bigl(\lfloor k\lambda\rfloor-\lfloor(k-1)\lambda\rfloor\bigr).
\]
An “Abel‐summation’’ (discrete integration by parts) gives
\[
\sum_{k=1}^n a_k\bigl(b_k-b_{k-1}\bigr)
=a_n\,b_n-\sum_{k=1}^{n-1}b_k\,(a_{k+1}-a_k),
\]
and here \(a_k=k\), \(b_k=\lfloor k\lambda\rfloor\), so \(a_{k+1}-a_k=1\).  Hence
\[
S_{\mathrm{ext}}(n)
=n\lfloor n\lambda\rfloor
\;-\;
\sum_{k=1}^{n-1}\lfloor k\lambda\rfloor.
\]
But for any real \(x\) we have \(x=\lfloor x\rfloor+\{x\}\), where
\(\{x\}\in[0,1)\) is the fractional part.  Thus
\[
\lfloor k\lambda\rfloor
=\;k\lambda-\{k\lambda\},
\]
and
\[
\sum_{k=1}^{n-1}\lfloor k\lambda\rfloor
=\sum_{k=1}^{n-1}\bigl(k\lambda-\{k\lambda\}\bigr)
=\lambda\,\frac{(n-1)n}2
\;-\;
\sum_{k=1}^{n-1}\{k\lambda\}.
\]
Also \(\lfloor n\lambda\rfloor=n\lambda-\{n\lambda\}\).  Substituting,
\[
\begin{aligned}
S_{\mathrm{ext}}(n)
&=n\bigl(n\lambda-\{n\lambda\}\bigr)
\;-\;
\Bigl[\lambda\,\tfrac{(n-1)n}2
-\sum_{k=1}^{n-1}\{k\lambda\}\Bigr]
\\
&=\lambda\,\frac{n^2+(n-1)n}2
\;+\;\sum_{k=1}^{n-1}\{k\lambda\}\;-\;n\{n\lambda\}
\\
&=\lambda\,\frac{n(n+1)}2
\;+\;\sum_{k=1}^{n-1}\{k\lambda\}\;-\;n\{n\lambda\}.
\end{aligned}
\]
Therefore if we set
\[
T(n)
\;=\;
S_{\mathrm{ext}}(n)
\;-\;
\lambda\,\frac{n(n+1)}2
\;=\;
\sum_{k=1}^{n-1}\{k\lambda\}
\;-\;
n\{n\lambda\},
\]
then proving (*) is equivalent to showing that \(T(n)\le0\) for infinitely many \(n\).

3. **Finding infinitely many \(n\) with \(T(n)<0\).**  
First note the trivial bound
\(
\sum_{k=1}^{n-1}\{k\lambda\}\le n-1,
\)
since each \(\{k\lambda\}<1\).  Hence
\[
T(n)
\le
(n-1)\;-\;n\,\{n\lambda\}
=\;
-\;1\;+\;\bigl(1-\{n\lambda\}\bigr)\,n.
\]
We distinguish two cases.

Case 1. \(\lambda\) is irrational.  
It is a classical and well‐known fact that the fractional parts \(\{n\lambda\}\) are dense in \([0,1]\).  In particular for each \(m\in\Bbb N\) there are infinitely many \(n\) with
\(
\{n\lambda\}>1-\tfrac1n.
\)
For any such \(n\),
\[
T(n)
\;\le\;
-1 + n\bigl(1-\{n\lambda\}\bigr)
\;<\;
-1+n\cdot\frac1n
=0.
\]
Hence \(T(n)<0\) infinitely often.

Case 2. \(\lambda=p/q\in\Q\) in lowest terms.  
Then \(\{n\lambda\}=\{np/q\}\) takes only the values \(0,\tfrac1q,\tfrac2q,\dots,\tfrac{q-1}q\) periodically.  In particular there is some residue class of \(n\pmod q\) for which
\(\{n\lambda\}=\tfrac{q-1}q\).  For such \(n\),
\[
T(n)
\;\le\;
(n-1)-n\cdot\frac{q-1}q
\;=\;
-\frac{n-1}q
\;<\;
0.
\]
Again there are infinitely many such \(n\).

In either case we have exhibited infinitely many \(n\) with \(T(n)<0\), i.e.\ 
\[
S_{\mathrm{ext}}(n)
\;<\;
\frac{n(n+1)}2\,\lambda.
\]
Since \(S(n)\le S_{\mathrm{ext}}(n)\), the same strict inequality holds for the original sum \(S(n)\) infinitely often.  This completes the proof.  ∎

result.summary:
The proof introduces the extremal sequence \(d_k=\lfloor k\lambda\rfloor-\lfloor(k-1)\lambda\rfloor\in\{0,1\}\), shows that for any feasible multiplicities \((g_k)\) one has \(S(n)=\sum k g_k\le S_{\mathrm{ext}}(n)=\sum k d_k\).  An Abel‐summation yields a closed form

\[S_{\mathrm{ext}}(n)=\frac{n(n+1)}2\,\lambda+\sum_{k=1}^{n-1}\{k\lambda\}-n\{n\lambda\},\]

defining \(T(n)=S_{\mathrm{ext}}(n)-\tfrac{n(n+1)}2\lambda\).  Since \(\sum_{k=1}^{n-1}\{k\lambda\}\le n-1\), one gets \(T(n)\le-1+n(1-\{n\lambda\})\).  In the irrational case density of \(\{n\lambda\}\) is invoked to find infinitely many \(n\) with \(T(n)<0\), and in the rational case periodicity of fractional parts gives the same conclusion.  Hence infinitely often \(S(n)\le\tfrac{n(n+1)}2\lambda\).

issues.text: “It is a classical and well‐known fact that the fractional parts \(\{n\lambda\}\) are dense in \([0,1]\). In particular for each \(m\in\mathbb{N}\) there are infinitely many \(n\) with \(\{n\lambda\}>1-\tfrac1n\).”
issues.description: The proof uses mere density to assert infinitely many solutions in the shrinking intervals \((1-1/n,1)\). Density guarantees points in any fixed subinterval, but not in a sequence of intervals whose lengths tend to zero; one needs a quantitative equidistribution or Diophantine approximation argument to conclude infinitely many \(n\) satisfy \(\{n\lambda\}>1-1/n\).

issues.text: “for each \(m\in\mathbb{N}\) there are infinitely many \(n\) with \(\{n\lambda\}>1-\tfrac1n\).”
issues.description: The phrase “for each \(m\in\mathbb{N}\)” is superfluous and appears to be a typographical error, since the statement does not depend on any choice of \(m\).
The proof invokes the Abel summation identity without proof or citation, skipping the justification of a non‐trivial summation technique that may not be immediate to all readers.

attempts.solution:
To solve the problem, we need to show that there are infinitely many \(n \in \mathbb{N}\) such that the sum of the elements in \(A_n\) is at most \(\lambda \frac{n(n+1)}{2}\), given that \(0 < \lambda < 1\) and \(|A_n| \leq n \lambda\) for all \(n\).

result.summary: The proof begins by reformulating the problem via multiplicities \(m_k\) for each integer in \(A\), intending to express \(|A_n|\) and the sum of elements in terms of these multiplicities but does not proceed further.

issues.description: The proof is truncated and incomplete, ending mid-sentence without further development or conclusion.
The proof does not derive the expressions \(|A_n|=\sum_{k=1}^n m_k\) or \(\sum_{a\in A_n}a=\sum_{k=1}^n k\,m_k\), skipping fundamental computations.
The hypothesis \(|A_n|\le n\lambda\) and the condition \(0<\lambda<1\) are never used or incorporated into any argument.
No argument is provided to establish that infinitely many \(n\) satisfy the desired inequality; the proof never reaches a conclusion.
